Curves 1 and 2 – bidentate formate (band 1550cm−1); curves 3 and 4 – monodentate formate (band 1668cm−1). Fig. 8 Surface complexes observed during adsorption of formic acid and water on the V–Ti oxide catalyst. Effect of water on decomposition of formic acid over V–Ti oxide catalyst: Kinetic and in situ FTIR study Galina Ya. Popova ⁎ Yuriy A. Chesalov ⁎ Ekaterina M. Sadovskaya Tamara V. Andrushkevich Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Russian Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation ⁎ Corresponding authors. Fax: +7 383 3308056. Graphical abstract The rates of CO (1) and CO2 (2) formation vs steady-state water concentration at formic acid decomposition over monolayer V–Ti oxide catalyst at 120 (a) and 140°C (b). Highlights ► Effect of water on decomposition of HCOOH over V–Ti catalyst was studied by kinetic and FTIR methods. ► CO and CO2 in a ratio of ∼9/1 are the products of the reaction. ► The addition of water vapor to the reaction mixture decreases the rate of formic acid decomposition. ► Formates are intermediates in CO x formation. ► Water accelerates the reverse reaction of HCOOH formation from formates. Decomposition of formic acid over V–Ti oxide catalyst in the absence and in the presence of water was studied by kinetic and in situ FTIR methods. CO and CO2 in a ratio of ∼9/1 are the products of decomposition of formic acid. Surface bidentate and monodentate formate ions are the products of formic acid adsorption at 120–140°C. Decrease in the rate of formic acid decomposition in the presence of water observed in the steady-state kinetic experiments is related with the competitive adsorption between H2O and formic acid and with the acceleration of the reverse reaction of formic acid formation from formates. Keywords V–Ti oxide catalyst Formic acid decomposition Water Kinetics In situ FTIR 1 Introduction According to the literature, water strongly affects the catalytic properties in many reactions of oxidation of hydrocarbons, especially during formation of carboxylic acids. The promoting action of water in selective oxidation of hydrocarbons is related mainly with facilitating desorption of oxygenates from the catalyst surface and/or modification of the catalyst structure [1–16]. It is shown that the presence of water in the feed leads to an increase in selectivity to carboxylic acids and a decrease in CO x formation during the oxidation acroline to acrylic acid [1–7], methacroline to methacrylic acid [8], β-picoline to nicotinic acid [9–11], propionaldehyde to propionic acid and acetaldehyde to acetic acid [12,13], propane to acrylic acid [14,15] over oxide vanadium containing catalysts. The role of water in the oxidation of 1-butene to acetic acid over VO x –TiO2 is associated with an acceleration of carboxylic acids desorption, and with the VOH species formation [13]. It was shown [13] that hydrated vanadium species exhibited high selectivity towards acetic acid formation whereas VO centers favored total oxidation. At the oxidation of toluene over vanadia–titania catalyst, the presence of steam increases the selectivity to benzoic acid due to formation of hydroxyl groups involved in hydrolysis of surface benzoates [17]. It was reported [18,19] that in the presence of a high steam concentration during the oxidation of toluene over V–TiO2 catalysts the benzoate species transform to benzoic acid. Vanadia–titania catalysts are active and selective in the oxidation of formaldehyde to formic acid [20–22]. The heterogeneous catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde into formic acid in the gas phase may be considered as an alternative to the multistep liquid-phase synthesis of formic acid. The investigation of kinetics and mechanism of formaldehyde oxidation over vanadia–titania catalyst were carried out in [23,24]. The selectivity in respect to formic acid attains 95–90% in the range of formaldehyde conversion of 20–90% at the reaction temperature of 120–140°C [24]. Waste products (CO and CO2) form via consecutive reactions of formic acid decomposition (scheme): Kinetic studies of formaldehyde oxidation over a monolayer V–Ti oxide catalyst revealed accelerating effect of water on the formic acid formation and inhibitory effect of water on the rate of carbon oxide formation [24]. The aim of this investigation is to elucidate the mechanism of the water interaction with the monolayer vanadia–titania catalyst and the reasons of decreasing reaction rate of formic acid decomposition. For this purpose, kinetic methods and FTIR spectroscopy were used to investigate the effect of water on formic acid decomposition over a monolayer V–Ti oxide catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A monolayer vanadia–titania (V–Ti) oxide catalyst was prepared by impregnation of TiO2 (anatase, catalog Alfa Aesar, S =350m2/g) with a solution of vanadium oxalate followed by drying at 110°C for 12h and calcination at 450°C in air for 4h [21,22]. Chemical composition of the catalyst is 7.3wt.%V2O5/92.7wt.%TiO2 (N s =8.9VO x /nm2). According to the XRD and Raman data, the catalyst consists of TiO2 (anatase) phase and polymeric VO x species [22]. 2.2 Catalytic tests Catalytic properties of the V–Ti oxide catalyst were studied in the reaction of formic acid decomposition at 120–140°C. The steady-state activity of the catalysts was tested at atmospheric pressure by the differential method in a flow circulation setup. The reactor (i.d. 12mm, length 50mm) was made of Pyrex glass with a coaxial thermocouple pocket (d =4mm) for temperature measurements in the catalyst bed. The reactor was placed in an electrical oven with air heating. The temperature was controlled with the accuracy ±0.5°C using a temperature controller. To prevent the product condensation, the circulation circuit was thermostated at 120°C. The catalyst fraction of 0.25–0.50mm was used. The composition of the initial mixture (vol.%) was as follows: 2% HCOOH, 0–23% Н2О, air the balance. The water and formic acid were dosed by saturation of air stream at a given temperature. The concentrations of formic acid and reaction products (CO and CO2) were determined chromatographically. The conversion of formic acid was calculated by equation: X = C HCOOH o − C HCOOH C HCOOH o × 100 ( % ) Here, C HCOOH o is the initial concentration of formic acid, C HCOOH is the outlet formic acid concentration, mol.%. The selectivity to CO and CO2 was calculated with respect to transformed molecules of HCOOH: S i = C i C HCOOH o − C HCOOH × 100 ( % ) Here, C i is the concentration of CO or CO2, mol.%. The steady-state rate (r i ) of the formic acid decomposition to CO or CO2 was calculated by equation: r i = F × C × 10 − 2 × X × 10 − 2 × S i × 6.03 × 10 23 22.4 × g × S BET ( molec m − 2 s − 1 ) , where F is the flow rate (l/s, normal condition) of the initial reaction mixture; C is the initial concentration of HCOOH (mol.%); X is the conversion of HCOOH (%); S is the selectivity to CO or CO2 (%); g is the catalyst weight (g); and S BET is the specific surface area of catalyst, m2 ×g−1. Carbon balance was at least 97±2% for all the experiments. 2.3 In situ FTIR experiments In situ FTIR spectroscopy experiments were performed in a flow IR cell reactor with a Bomem MB-102 FTIR spectrometer in the temperature range of 120–140°C. The catalyst powder (35–50mg) was pressed into a self-supported 1cm×3cm wafer. The wafer was mounted into a quartz IR cell reactor with CaF2 windows, activated in air flow (50cm3/min) at 250°C for 60min, and then cooled to the desired temperature. Spectra of the sample were recorded as a background values. Formic acid (HCOOH, A.C.S. reagent grade, 99% purity) was obtained from Aldrich. In the case of an adsorption experiments, a mixture of 1vol.% HCOOH or 1% HCOOH+4%H2O or 4%H2O in air was introduced to the IR cell reactor at 120–140°C. The IR spectra were recorded with a resolution of 4cm−1 and with an accumulation of 20 scans. In the case of formic acid desorption experiments, after establishing a stationary covering with the surface complexes, a 1% HCOOH/air gas mixture was replaced with the air or 4%H2O in air flow, and then the desorption kinetics of surface complexes was studied. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The catalytic decomposition of HCOOH over V–Ti–O catalyst. Effect of water Decomposition of HCOOH over V–Ti oxide catalyst at 120–140°C results in the formation of CO and CO2 in a ratio of ∼9/1. The influence of water vapor on the formation rates and selectivities of CO and CO2 was investigated in the presence of 0–23vol.% water vapor at the concentrations of acid 2.0vol.% and oxygen 18vol.%. Fig. 1 shows the dependences of СО and СО2 formation rates on the concentration of water vapor at 120 and 140°С. The rates of CO and CO2 formation dramatically decrease upon addition of water vapor to the reaction mixture. Changes in the selectivities follow those of the rates. Selectivity to СО decreases and selectivity to СО2 increases with raising the concentration of water. 3.2 In situ FTIR study of formic acid adsorption Fig. 2 shows FTIR spectrum of the sample in the range of 4000–1200cm−1 before the adsorption at 120°C. The bands at 3650 and 2036cm−1 due to stretching mode of OH-group and first overtone of stretching vibration of VO-group, respectively, are observed in the spectrum of the catalyst. Fig. 3 shows FTIR spectra registered at 120 (a) and 140°C (b) upon increasing the time of formic acid adsorption (reaction mixture is 1%HCOOH in air). Three groups of the bands can be distinguished; their intensities change irrespective of each other when adsorption time is increased or temperature is varied, which allows assigning these bands to three types of surface compounds [25]: (1) molecularly adsorbed formic acid (ν(CH) = 2945cm−1, ν(CO)=1720cm−1 and ν(CO)=1180cm−1); (2) bidentate formate ions (ν s(СОО)+ δ(СН)=2960cm−1, ν(СН)=2883cm−1, ν as(СОО)=1550cm−1, δ(СН)=1375cm−1, ν s(СОО)=1365cm−1); (3) monodentate formate ions (ν as(СОО)=1668cm−1, ν s(СОО)=1250cm−1). In the difference spectra the ν(OH) band at 3650cm−1 has negative intensity (Fig. 3). The negative intensity indicates that the concentration of the surface OH groups decreases during adsorption of the acid. This may be related with the formation of hydrogen bonds between surface complexes of formic acid and OH groups of the catalyst. Indeed, in IR spectra there is a broad band at 3500–3000cm−1 with a maximum near 3270cm−1, which characterizes OH groups disturbed by the hydrogen bonds. Intensity of this band grows with increasing the surface concentration of formate ions. Fig. 4 shows IR spectra obtained for the adsorption of water (a) and joint adsorption of formic acid and water (b) at 120°C with increasing adsorption time. Water adsorption (Fig. 4a) leads to appearance of the band at ∼1620cm−1 assigned to δ(Н2О) mode of adsorbed water. Intensity of this band grows when adsorption time increases to 600s, and then retains its value. A gradual decrease in intensity of the band 3650cm−1 corresponding to hydroxyl groups of the catalyst is accompanied by the appearance and growth of a broad complex absorption in the region of 3500–2600cm−1. The latter can be attributed to ν as(Н2О) and ν s(Н2О) vibrations of adsorbed water and ν(ОН) vibrations of hydroxyl groups involved in the formation of hydrogen bonds. Besides, as the time of adsorption increases, the ν(ОН) band at 3680cm−1 appears and grows in intensity, which indicates that water on this catalyst is also adsorbed dissociatively to form hydroxyl groups. The addition of a 1%НСООН+4% Н2О in air mixture results in immediate appearance of the bands corresponding to coordinated water (1620cm−1), H-bound water, and OH groups (a broad absorption at 3500–2600cm−1 with a maximum near 3250cm−1 and band at 3680cm−1) (Fig. 4b). The latter band, as was demonstrated above, is caused by dissociative adsorption of water. Along with bands of adsorbed water, there appear bands of surface complexes of the acid, namely, bidentate formates (ν as(COO)=1550cm−1 and ν s(COO)=1365cm−1). A distinctive feature of formic acid adsorption in the presence of water vapor is the absence of the bands of monodentate formate ions in IR spectra (Fig. 4b). As for the bidentate formates bands, their intensities show a pronounced (∼20-fold) decrease. Fig. 5a and b depict the time dependences of the intensity of bands of surface complexes during formic acid adsorption in the absence (a) and in the presence (b) of water vapor in the reaction mixture at 120°С. In the absence of water vapor, surface bidentate formates (band 1550cm−1) start to form virtually immediately after addition of the acid. Monodentate formates (band 1668cm−1) and H-bound acid (band 1720cm−1) are formed with a delay of ca. 150s. The intensity of the band of the catalyst OH group (3650cm−1) changes oppositely to the concentration of monodentate formates (band 1668cm−1) and H-bound acid. This may be related both with the formation of H-bound formic acid involving the catalyst OH groups and the formation of hydrogen bonds with monodentate formates. As intensity of the catalyst OH group the band (3650cm−1) decreases, the intensity of the band at 3270cm−1 (OH groups disturbed by the hydrogen bond) increases. Total amount of adsorbed acid at 120°С is 1.6×1018 molec/m2. In this case, covering with bidentate formates calculated with the extinction coefficient (ν as(СОО) band) ɛ =5×10−19 cm2/molec [26,27] is 1.3×1018 molec/m2, i.e., approximately 80% of the acid is adsorbed as bidentate formates. Covering with monodentate formates and Н-bound acid is equal to 0.3×1018 molec/m2. Kinetic dependences that are observed for joint adsorption of formic acid and water vapor have a different form (Fig. 5b). Feeding the reaction mixture results in simultaneous formation of bidentate formates (band 1550cm−1), molecularly adsorbed water (the band 1620cm−1), and dissociatively adsorbed water (band 3680cm−1). In the initial period of adsorption (up to ∼400s), there is a parallel growth in the concentration of surface complexes of the acid and water. Then, concentration of bidentate formates monotonically decreases, whereas covering with the water adsorption products monotonically increases. The observed pattern of changes in the concentration of surface complexes indicates a competitive mechanism of water and acid adsorption. This assumption is supported by a ∼20 times lower covering with bidentate formates in the presence of water vapor at the same concentration of the acid in the gas phase. Monodentate formate ions are not detected in the presence of water vapor. This may be related with overlap between the bands of δ(H2O) of adsorbed water and ν as(СОО) of monodentate formate ions and low concentration of the latter complex due to competitive adsorption of Н2О and НСООН at the same sites. 3.3 In situ FTIR study of formic acid desorption Kinetic curves for the surface formate decomposition were obtained at 120 and 140°С in two parallel experiments. After establishing the stationary covering with surface complexes upon formic acid adsorption, a flow of composition 1%HCOOH in air was switched over to air (desorption in the air, Fig. 6a and c) or to a mixture of 4% Н2О in air (desorption in the air–vapor mixture, Fig. 6b and d). After replacing the reaction mixture by air, the bands of surface formates decrease in intensity, the band of molecularly adsorbed acid disappears (Figs. 6a and c), and band intensity of the catalyst OH group at 3650cm−1 is restored. During desorption in the air–vapor mixture (Figs. 6b and d), a decrease in intensity of adsorbed acid bands is accompanied by increasing intensity of the band at 3650cm−1 due to the catalyst OH group (intensity of the negative peak decreases), by formation of coordinatively bound water (1620cm−1), and appearance of OH group band at 3680cm−1. Fig. 7 shows the relaxation dependences of the intensities of the bands of bidentate (ν as(COO)=1550cm−1) and monodentate (ν as(COO)=1668cm−1) formates at 120 and 140°С when composition of the reaction mixture was switched over in the following order: air→1% HCOOH/air→air (or4%H2O/air) Water dramatically accelerates decomposition of both bidentate and monodentate formates. According to IR spectroscopy data, there are two factors that can explain an abrupt decrease in the rate of formic acid decomposition over the V–Ti oxide catalyst in the presence of water vapor observed in the steady-state kinetic experiments. First of all, the rate of formic acid decomposition decreases due to competitive adsorption of water and formic acid at the same sites. The structure of surface compounds produced upon interaction of the V–Ti oxide catalyst with formic acid and water is presented in Fig. 8 . On the V–Ti oxide catalyst, adsorption sites are represented by isolated surface OH groups, Lewis acid sites (cationic positions), and surface oxygen atoms of the catalyst. The interaction of acid and water with OH groups leads to hydrogen-bound complexes of the acid (SS1) and water (SS4). Dissociative adsorption of formic acid yielding surface formates (SS2 and SS3) involves the MeO acid–base pair. Water is dissociatively adsorbed at the same sites to form OH groups (SS6). Lewis acid sites (Me) take part also in the formation of coordinatively bound water (SS5). In supported monolayer V–Ti oxide catalyst, VO x particles serve as the MeO sites. Different structure of formates (bidentate SS2 and monodentate SS3) is caused by the presence of different forms of VO x particles. TPR curves having more than one maximum confirm that VO x particles in the tested sample are inhomogeneous [22]. Earlier it was shown [28] that the products of surface formates conversion over V–Ti oxide catalyst are not only СО and СО2, but also formic acid due to reversibility of the formates formation step: (1) HCOOH+[V–Os]↔HCOO–V+OsH→CO x +H2O As was shown above, the rate of CO x formation decreases upon addition of water vapor to the reaction mixture. Contrariwise, water accelerates formates decomposition. It can be concluded from analysis of kinetics and IR data that water vapor accelerates the reverse reaction rather than the step of formates decomposition into CO x (Eq. (1)), which shows up as a decrease in decomposition rate of formic acid during the steady-state experiments. 4 Conclusion Decomposition of HCOOH in the air flow at 120–140°C over V–Ti–O catalyst results in the formation of CO and CO2 in a ratio of ∼9/1. The addition of water vapor to the reaction mixture strongly decreases the rate of formic acid decomposition. In situ FTIR study showed that formic acid adsorption on V–Ti oxide catalyst leads to bidentate and monodentate formates. Water dramatically accelerates decomposition of both bidentate and monodentate formates. The suppression effect of water vapor on decomposition of formic acid may be related with the competitive adsorption between H2O and formic acid on the active sites of V–Ti oxide catalyst and with increase in the rate of formates conversion to formic acid due to a growing concentration of surface protons caused by water adsorption. coredata.dc:description: Decomposition of formic acid over V–Ti oxide catalyst in the absence and in the presence of water was studied by kinetic and in situ FTIR methods. CO and CO2 in a ratio of ∼9/1 are the products of decomposition of formic acid. Surface bidentate and monodentate formate ions are the products of formic acid adsorption at 120–140°C. Decrease in the rate of formic acid decomposition in the presence of water observed in the steady-state kinetic experiments is related with the competitive adsorption between H2O and formic acid and with the acceleration of the reverse reaction of formic acid formation from formates.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of water on decomposition of formic acid over V–Ti oxide catalyst: Kinetic and in situ FTIR study
